segments.en: Linked Discourses 3
2. Childless
13. A Bucket of Rice
At Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo doṇapākakuraṃ bhuñjati.
segments.en: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala used to eat rice by the bucket.

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhuttāvī mahassāsī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: Then after eating King Pasenadi of Kosala went up to the Buddha, huffing and puffing. He bowed and sat down to one side.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā rājānaṃ pasenadiṃ kosalaṃ bhuttāviṃ mahassāsiṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
segments.en: Then, knowing that King Pasenadi was huffing and puffing after eating, on that occasion the Buddha recited this verse:
“When a man is always mindful,
knowing moderation in eating,
his discomfort diminishes,
and he ages slowly, taking care of his life.”

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sudassano māṇavo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa piṭṭhito ṭhito hoti.
segments.en: Now at that time the brahmin student Sudassana was standing behind the king.

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo sudassanaṃ māṇavaṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: Then King Pasenadi addressed him,

segments.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, tāta sudassana, bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā mama bhattābhihāre bhattābhihāre bhāsa.
segments.en: “Please, dear Sudassana, memorize this verse in the Buddha’s presence and recite it to me whenever I am presented with a meal.

segments.pli: Ahañca te devasikaṃ kahāpaṇasataṃ kahāpaṇasataṃ niccaṃ bhikkhaṃ pavattayissāmī”ti.
segments.en: I’ll set up a regular daily allowance of a hundred dollars for you.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho sudassano māṇavo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa paṭissutvā bhagavato santike imaṃ gāthaṃ pariyāpuṇitvā rañño pasenadissa kosalassa bhattābhihāre sudaṃ bhāsati:
segments.en: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Sudassana. He memorized that verse in the Buddha’s presence, and then whenever the king was presented with a meal he would repeat it:
“When a man is always mindful,
knowing moderation in eating,
his discomfort diminishes,
and he ages slowly, taking care of his life.”

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo anupubbena nāḷikodanaparamatāya saṇṭhāsi.
segments.en: Then the king gradually got used to having no more than a pint of rice.

segments.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo aparena samayena susallikhitagatto pāṇinā gattāni anumajjanto tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
segments.en: After some time King Pasenadi’s body slimmed right down. Stroking his limbs with his hands, at that time he was inspired to exclaim:

segments.pli: “ubhayena vata maṃ so bhagavā atthena anukampi—
segments.en: “The Buddha truly has compassion for me in both
the good of the present life and the good of the next life.”

suttaplex.blurb: In what is probably the world’s first weight loss diet, when Pasenadi shows up overweight and out of breath, the Buddha advises him to cut down his eating. He gives a verse to one of the king’s attendants, and asks him to recite it whenever the king is eating.
